'speaker_4': 'This bill, as stated, would establish the legal name of the pedestrian and bike bicycle bridge connecting North Seattle College to the North Gate Light Rail Station Opening October 2nd as the John Lewis Memorial Bridge. As a former community matter member and then a constituent and now an elected, I have been involved in the pedestrian bridge since at'

'speaker_4': 'least 2015, and I think we raised we finally got it up to about $56 million with the city of Seattle putting in the most money to make this happen. This bill constitutes months, if not years, of collaboration with our community.'

'speaker_4': 'We started by completing a citywide inventory of all the names of public infrastructures in the city of Seattle. And what we found was that there was very little bipoc representation citywide and in District five. There's currently not a single school, park, street, library, pool, community center or any natural habitat such as a river, lake creek or stream'

'speaker_4': 'named after an African-American leader. And we do know that through sale public schools, we have the vocal staff, Robert Eagle Staff School, which I knew Bob and the Northgate Elementary School, I understand, will be changed soon to the James Baldwin School.'

'speaker_4': 'So I'm working citywide and with community. We considered many names for this bridge and decided to put forward the name of the honorable U.S. Representative John Lewis, who we lost a year ago last July. John Lewis passed away on July 17, 2020, after serving as a U.S. representative for Georgia's fifth Congressional District for more than three decades'

'speaker_4': '. In honor of his incredible life and legacy as a civil rights icon and voting rights advocate, I'm sponsoring this bill along with Councilmember Purple, to name the pedestrian bicycle bridge in Northgate, the John Lewis Memorial Bridge. I was joined in committee by two incredible community members, former King County Council member Larry Gossett and president of North Steel'

'speaker_4': 'College, Dr. Charmaine Crawford. Both Councilmember Gossett and Dr. Crawford support the naming to recognize and remembered the vital nationwide impact John Lewis made during his time as a civil rights activist, activist, advocate, and as a member of Congress.'

'speaker_4': 'We have some interesting comments in during this period in the last year about naming John Lewis after this particular bridge. And again, I just want to point out something that it should be obvious, but this is why we have this opportunity to look at places and memorialize people and that we remember, to be honest to the history'

'speaker_4': ', not only about who gets remembered, but how they get remembered and why they get remembered. John Lewis was a friend of Councilmember Gossett, and Dr. Charmaine Crawford spoke both times about how she met Mr. John Lewis. But all of this side, I don't think that we should have to qualify any black leader, any indigenous leader, any Asian'

'speaker_4': 'leader, any LGBTQ leader. I don't think that we have to qualify that. They have some incorrect, incredible, direct connection to the city of Seattle. I don't think George Washington was here or Lincoln or, you know, Franklin or, you know, Jason Lee or, you know, let's see.'

'speaker_4': 'I can't think of other names. They're everywhere, as you all know. And I think we should also point out that John Thornton, where we have Thornton Creek in Thornton Place, was a railroad speculator who never came to King County or Seattle and actually lived and died in Clough County.'

'speaker_4': 'But got his name, got the title for the creek up here through the Bureau of Land Management in 1889. And I'm not saying that to disparage people who wanted that name. I understand and I get it. And we have sorted creek and we have in place.'

'speaker_4': 'But I think it's time that we we opened that that lens that there are other people that have made this country great and they didn't necessarily have to physically be here, though John Lewis did come to the University of Washington, I believe, in 2017, because in particular, when people of that greatness, of that magnitude change our minds'

'speaker_4': 'and our hearts, we owe it not only to the Honorable John Lewis, but to everybody to remember who John Lewis was. I want to close up by saying something that I also shared in committee and I shared with other folks as well, is that we believe that when loved ones leave us that they don't actually leave us'

'speaker_4': 'and they are alive as long as we say their name. So it's important that we say John Lewis's name so people know who John Lewis was, what he did, and what he did for this country and how he what he committed to, not only in his personal life, but his professional life.'

'speaker_4': 'There are very few heroes that we have like that, quite frankly, that I actually believe in. So this bridge is both symbolic and poetic. When John Lewis led the civil rights march in from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama, as you know, they were attacked by state troopers attempting to cross the Edmund Pettus Bridge.'

'speaker_4': 'The violent attacks were recorded and disseminated throughout the country and the images proved too powerful to ignore. That became Bloody Sunday as the day was labeled, which sped up the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. And as I shared in committee, that was the 1965, 56 years ago.'

'speaker_4': 'And as you all know, we are still fighting for the John Lewis Voting Act. We are still fighting for a bedrock of our democracy and people's right to vote. And that is still going on. And I'm hoping that this bridge will be a reminder and not just a reminder for the city of Seattle, but for anybody what'

'speaker_4': 'this bridge means and also how we commemorate and honor those who have done great things for our country. 'speaker_4': '. And I believe that I hope that he inspires all of us as leaders and future leaders to do the same. Resolution on Urban Renewal, Displacemen: 'speaker_4': 'Agenda Item 18. Resolution 32015. Regarding the impact of Seattle's Urban Renewal Program in displacing black community members from the central area, supporting community demands to fund quality, affordable social housing to prevent and reverse displacement. And urging the Office of Housing to fund the Affordable Housing Project.'
'speaker_4': 'Proposed by New Hope Community Development Institute.'
'speaker_0': 'Thank you. I move adoption of resolution 32015. Is there a second?'
'speaker_2': 'Second.'
'speaker_0': 'Thank you, Councilmember Swan. Councilor Swan, as sponsor of this item, you're recognized in order to address it.'

'speaker_2': 'Thank you, President Pro-Tem Peterson. This is a resolution that my office worked on with Dr. Reverend Jeffrey of the New Hope Missionary Baptist Church. Pastors of other black churches and the United Black Clergy as a whole. The Church Council of Greater Seattle and the Low Income Housing Institute and many Central District community members.'

'speaker_2': 'By approving this resolution, the City Council will acknowledge the city's past policies of racist displacement, such as redlining, urban renewal. And we don't seed and urge all city departments to look for opportunities to make reparations for those past injustices.'

'speaker_2': 'Urged the Office of Housing to fund the new Hope Family Housing Project, which will create 86 affordable homes in the Central District to their families with historic roots in the neighborhood. You know, the working families who are displaced because of these redlining policies and also in the ensuing years, because of skyrocketing rent, can afford to come and'

'speaker_2': 'I can afford to stay if they're at risk of displacement or they can afford to return. With the new affordable housing available. Commit to expand city funding for affordable housing projects made available in 2021 and forum support for increasing progressive taxes on big business and the rich to develop more quality, affordable social housing.'

'speaker_2': 'I thank the new Hope Church community and so many others for helping to organize and for speaking at the amazing rally we held on Saturday, July 31st, in support of the resolution, in support of the Affordable Housing by the New Hope Church, and in support of expanding funding for such community projects so that we are not forced'

'speaker_2': 'to compete with one another over pennies while the wealth gap in this city continues expanding at a stunning rate. All affordable housing that can be built is needed right now, given the steep affordability crisis, and it is the obligation of elected officials to expand the progressive revenues available for this.'

'speaker_2': 'Special thanks to former King County Councilmember Larry Gossett, who spoke at the rally and who spoke today in public comment and also in public comment last Monday. And also I wanted to recognize against some resistance and the new executive director of the Economic Opportunity Institute, who also came out to speak at the rally that Saturday.'

'speaker_2': 'Members of the public may also have seen an excellent op ed in the Seattle Times on July 16, authored by Reverend Jeffrey, who, as you all know, is a senior pastor of the New Hope Church, which is the historically black church in the Central District.'

'speaker_2': 'And in that op ed, Reverend Jeffrey notes that in 1969, the city forced the new Hope Church and black homeowners. In this very area to sell their land under the threat of eminent domain for Spruce Street Mini Park, the city's establishment at the time sought the elimination of the Central District's vibrant black neighborhood, which included working people'

'speaker_2': 'and also black small businesses and the political establishment at that time, both in Seattle and nationwide, but put massive resources into what they called urban renewal, which is a very deceptive, euphemistic storm that has that spelled displacement and destruction for black communities in the Central District.'

'speaker_2': 'This so-called renewal project was named the Atlantic Urban Renewal Project and then later named the U.S.. Neighborhood Improvement Project. Which again, is misleading because it basically destroyed the neighborhood that existed at that time. The man and the city council at the time literally passed literally dozens of bills spanning over a decade, gathering federal grants, contracting with consultants'

'speaker_2': 'and forcing black homeowners and judges to sell their land. And the report from the consultants, the Seattle Urban Renewal Enterprise, made their intention clear. It describes the Central District as, quote, home to the colored, the poor, the ignorant, the unfortunate, the undesirable, the weak and the undeserving poor.'

'speaker_2': 'This is all quoted from the report. In 1961, the Seattle Urban Renewal Enterprise submitted to the city its funding report and summary, which claimed that, quote, to preserve this community for, quote unquote, decent folks and families, three things are needed assistance to those who need it and improving their way of life in every respect.'

'speaker_2': 'Encouragement to middle and upper income whites to move into the community. And three relocation of those undesirables. The purveyors of mice and crime. The chronic troublemakers. The undeserving poor who are the source of the most social blight in the area, end quote.'

'speaker_2': 'And following that report, city officials used the threat of eminent domain to force the new Hope Church and the neighboring black homeowners to sell their properties. The city created, quote unquote, incentives, as they stated in their intent for middle and upper class white families to move into the area to supposedly, quote unquote, revitalize the area.'

'speaker_2': 'In other words, the city's political establishment committed a stunning outrage and egregious theft of black resources, of working people's resources and legalized racist redlining and gentrification. This is a resolution which means that it only has the power to state an intention from the city council.'

'speaker_2': 'It is extremely important as the first step, but I would also make sure members of the public and community, members of the Central District recognize, as many did in public comment today, that this is not the budget legislation and that our people's budget movement will need to follow this up in the autumn with a real struggle to'

'speaker_2': 'win funding for to compensate the community members displaced over decades. And my office, of course, is dedicating to support that struggle. And we will be building the people's budget campaign, as we have done every year for the past seven years.'

'speaker_2': 'The property that the New Hope Church was forced to relinquish to the city in 1969 is estimated to be worth $2 million today, over eight times the inflation adjusted amount it was sold for. We know that those those injustices need to be corrected, but it's not just about what happened in the past.'

'speaker_2': 'It's about today. The city being unaffordable and the new hope effort is very much part of the thousands of community members who are fighting for an affordable city. We need to continue to tax big business and the super rich, which is basically expand the Amazon tax in the city.'

'speaker_2': 'We also need statewide efforts for taxes on wealthy household households, all those billionaires who have profited immensely of the injustice of capitalism in general, but also have pocketed tremendous amounts during the pandemic when hundreds of thousands of households statewide were impoverished because of loss of jobs or income.'

'speaker_2': 'As a first step. This resolution urges the Office of Housing to fund the new Hope Family Housing Project. But as I said, that is just the first step. We also need our dad Thomas on Movement to continue pushing for funding.'

'speaker_2': 'Many community activists, Reverend Young, who also spoke today and has been shoulder to shoulder every step of the way with the black community in the Central District and many socialists, particularly members from Socialist Alternative. 'speaker_2': 'I also wanted to recognize a real change by Seattle, the Tenants Union and Lehigh, all renters rights and housing justice organizations that have supported this effort. 'speaker_0': 'Thank you, Councilmember Swan. Colleagues, any other comments on this resolution? 32015. Councilmember Mosquito.'

'speaker_3': 'Thank you very much. Council President Pro Tem. I want to thank Councilmember Salant for working with my office. I don't think it was mentioned that we did a lot of work with her office, with Ted and Aaron House, working together on the no fund language on this resolution to reflect the language we already passed in the Jumpstart'

'speaker_3': 'Seattle Protected Fund legislation. You might remember just a few weeks ago, we passed legislation to make sure that all of the funding coming in from Jumpstart went into a siloed fund so that we can ensure accountability and transparency, and that the spend plan that we all jointly worked on together that passed unanimously was fully adhered to.'

'speaker_3': 'In that bill, we expressed our intent to increase the 2021 no fund through this year's budget process. The current no amount sits at around $35 million, which the legislation in front of us fully acknowledges is not sufficient, not sufficient to fund all of the projects that are shovel ready as we continue to work to scale up affordable'

'speaker_3': 'housing investments, especially in the wake of COVID. So very much in support of the effort to make sure that we are forward spending the no fight investments that we know are desperately needed right now. And this is a great example of what we should be funding now with the expected revenue to come.'

'speaker_3': 'I also want to recognize the importance of funding affordable housing that is rooted in and driven by communities, especially communities of color, especially communities in the Central District, our black communities that have been disproportionately impacted by discriminatory and racist policies of the past, like urban renewal, like redlining, like our current exclusionary zoning strategies.'

'speaker_3': 'This is part of the reason that I sponsored and we passed the 2018 Racial Equity Toolkit that was just discussed in the Land Use Committee. Finally, last week excuse me, last month, and it explains a lot about how the lived experience of those who've been testifying, meeting after meeting in support of this effort today have been caused'

'speaker_3': 'by and perpetuated by our city's exclusionary zoning policies and how important it is for us to use public policy tools to really change those those exclusionary policies that may have had name changes over the years, but are still very much just as harmful.'

'speaker_3': 'The Council also passed legislation making sure that we were expressly directing the executive department to every time that we had the opportunity to use public dollars to make sure that they were going into community focused acquisition and development for communities that were formerly red lives.'

'speaker_3': 'Communities that are still dealing with the legacy of that redlining. And folks who have been shut out of previous home ownership opportunities and thus also had limited ability to acquire generational wealth because of those racist lending policies of the past.'

'speaker_3': 'Some of the ways that we are hoping to continue to couple efforts like today's resolution with public policy and funding policy is to make sure that the funds are going to those who have been disproportionately affected by discriminatory lending practices of the past.'

'speaker_3': 'So one example is in the 2008 Housing and Administration Finance Plan on page 59. It says the objectives of the department, meaning the Department of Office of Housing, should be to prioritize partnerships and prioritize development proposals submitted by organizations led by and accountable to communities most impacted by displacement whenever available sites are located in neighborhoods with high'

'speaker_3': 'risk of displacement. We then followed up this legislation with your efforts this year, colleagues in the Seattle Rescue Plan, one in Section eight. We built upon that language from the administration of finance plan specifically for our efforts to try to house more folks who have been disproportionately affected by COVID.'

'speaker_3': 'And that includes high proportions of folks from our black communities in Seattle. Section eight says the city will prioritize opportunities to partner with local community based organizations that are culturally relevant and historically rooted in and founded by communities that have been disproportionately impacted by COVID, have organizational leadership, staff and board composition that reflect the communities they serve'

'speaker_3': 'for the purposes of direct grants and or allocations of grants. And you'll remember that we put about $50 million in the Seattle rescue plan. So we're trying to really tell the department, tell the departments and the executive to target those investments so that we can have more black communities, really have the opportunity to access those funds first'

'speaker_3': '. I greatly appreciate the organizing that has happened with New Hope and the community at large, which heard from a number of folks over the last few meetings about how this project is ready to go. And I look forward as the budget process starts to make sure that we are funding these efforts in the fall process.'

'speaker_3': 'We know that the project is somewhere between pre-development and shovel ready and that they're likely to apply for all of the funds. And with additional funds available through Jumpstart, we will be able to really prioritize the community driven projects like this through an plan, through jumpstart, through resolutions like the one we have in front of us today'

'speaker_3': 'to make sure that we're supporting and and and expanding our commitment through Office of Housing Investments to make sure that these projects get the funding that they need. We also need to make sure that we're reducing and removing partnership requirement barriers.'

'speaker_3': 'This is something I've heard directly from communities that have met with me, from black clergy, who've also echoed many of the things that I've heard from communities like in the Latino community and the Filipino community who have been trying to create more affordable housing across this city.'

'speaker_3': 'And they have been faced with this requirement for a partnership that really removes the ability for them to have ownership and control and direction over the land and the housing that they're trying to create. So in addition to supporting efforts like this and the funding that's required, we will be working through this year's budget to remove those'

'speaker_3': 'covenant requirements, remove the partnership requirements that have been a major barrier to especially communities of color who've been trying to create housing, self-directed housing for communities hardest hit by displacement. I am looking forward to also continuing conversations about expanding opportunities for progressive revenue.'

'speaker_3': 'I've been long in support of making sure that we have all progressive revenue options that we can advance. And the city that and the state that has long been plagued by one of the most regressive tax systems in our country.'

'speaker_3': 'And I see this effort as a broad statement to say that we will continue to advance progressive revenue strategies so that we can layer current progressive sources to make sure that we actually create that scale of funding needed to invest in affordable housing and so many other crises that are affecting our communities, especially our black community, that'

'speaker_3': 'has been disproportionately affected by redlining, previous racist covenants in our existing zoning strategies. So thank you for bringing this forward and thinks, Councilmember Swan for your office's work with with Aaron House to include some language regarding the Nova.'

'speaker_0': 'Thank you. Any comments from any other council members and with the council, our final word on on our resolution. Councilor Swan, any final comments on the resolution?'
